+ if box on roll 1 (.5*.5*.2) = 5%

Chance not gold: 56.8% not even considering the potential to get four empties after rolling two boxes on stage 2.

Chance of winning.
30%
+51% chance of winning on second round if box was rolled * 20% = 10.2%
As stated before, the chance of at least one box at round two is 7.2%. in 7.2% of interactions you will reach these third and fourth boxes and at least one will have gold at 51% odds. Total chances here 7.62% * 51% = 3.67%

Total chances to win = 43.87%

Total % chance of outcomes 100.67%, and I didn't even get into the possibility of box/box in round two,

A calculation is the process of using mathematical operations, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, to determine the value of an expression or solve a problem. Calculations can be done by hand or with the aid of a calculator or computer.

In algebra, equations are used to describe relationships between different quantities, and the goal is to find the value of an unknown quantity that satisfies the equation. In this context, the number 1 is a constant that is already defined and does not need to be constructed. It is often represented by the symbol "1" in equations and expressions, and it has the property that it is the multiplicative identity, meaning that any number multiplied by 1 is equal to that number.

Calculus is so beautiful when you think about it.

Here the black function is the derivative of blue and blue is the derivative of green. The lowest point of blue reveals where the green is the steepest. And the intersection with the x-axis of the black one reveals where the lowest point of blue is.

So the steepest point of a function f(x) can be found by differentiating it twice, finding f''(x), making that equal to zero and solving for x. So beautiful. I just had to post this because it's beautiful.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>15050015
Because there's a distinction between fixing a set and fixing all the elements in a set.
Consider for example the group of rotations on the plane. The only rotations that fix lines going through the origin are the 0 rotation and the 180 degrees rotation, but the only one that fixes the points on the line is the identity.
>Why is V≤U?
If a symmetry fixes all points in a set then it also needs to fix the whole set.

It is indeed interesting to consider the possibility that our universe could be simulated by a slower processor. The concept of simulating a universe has been explored in both science and science fiction, and while it is purely theoretical at this point, it raises many interesting questions about the nature of time and reality.

In a deterministic universe, all events are determined by their causes, and if we had perfect knowledge of the state of the universe at a given time, we would be able to predict all future events with certainty. The division between fields at the research level is somewhat arbitrary. In its broadest sense you could say it's physicists using physics approaches to answer questions motivated by/originating from chemistry. In practice "physics approaches" and "questions originating from chemistry" probably won't be so clear-cut. It doesn't really matter anyway, a physicist and a chemist studying quantum dot emission processes experimentally will probably develop a very similar skillset even if they didn't start out as such. It's not like anyone actually working in these fields really spends time thinking about exactly what subfield of science they should be categorized in.

last_replies.com: H basically measures the energy of a lattice system, J_{ij} is the value assigned to an edge (interaction), \sigma_i is the value assigned to a node. When combined with the Boltzmann distribution, essentially exponential with a tempering parameter, it can be interpreted as the probability of the system being in a given configuration. High-energy configurations have lower probability. Normalization is intractable because you need to sum over all possible configurations, but you can use e.g. Markov Chain Monte Carlo, in which you compare probability ratios (normalization constant cancels out).

name: Anonymous
sub: Can a Turing machine be conscious?
com: Computational theory of mind says that our minds are software running on hardware, and are essentially isomorphic to a sufficiently complex AI running on a computer, from which somehow a notion of consciousness emerges. What happens if you took that sufficiently complex AI software, and ran it on a Turing machine reduced down to an absurd level? For example, you have a very long dirt road, and a very large bag of rocks, and a very large book of the machine's states. You draw the gridded tape in the dirt with your finger along the road, and place rocks down in the grid squares to represent ones, and no rock for zeroes. After a very long time you place all your rocks down to initialise your AI program, then you begin to compute the program (very slowly) as if you were the Turing machine. Is the AI still conscious now? It's still being computed in the same way as if it were on advanced hardware, but when put this way it seems absurd that a system of lines on the dirt and rocks could be conscious. So you either reject computational theory of mind, or accept that consciousness is much more universal than we'd otherwise have thought.

Although ATP is chemically identical regardless of mode of production, glucose, with its six oxygens, may independently provide sufficient oxygen to produce ATP anaerobically if the mitochondria's process for handling glucose is altered. All six oxygens, some of which may have otherwise been discarded in the ATP production process, are all used in this mode of ATP production.

Although this difference, if its existence is confirmed, would not bestow an aerobic lifeform with the ability to survive without oxygen, the epigenetic changes to the mitochrondria caused by this type of as-yet unidentified dimension of hypothyroidism mimic those changes that would be observed in a lifeform that has been forced to adapt to reduced oxygen levels.

The result is that an individual lacking in the as-yet unidentified "thyroid hormone X;" more than likely not a hormone but an mRNA; would have an altered mitochronial metabolism that more efficiently utilizes oxygens in glucose molecules, eschewing available oxygen from hemoglobin. The net result would be a patient that has reduced body temperature (as less O2 is being metabolized relative to glucose) and that a patient's weight is hyperstabilized regardless of T4 supplementation.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
When T4 is supplemented, the thyroid is freed to produce the "X" mRNA in greater quantities as it may focus its efforts entirely on non-T4/T3 production. I furthermore would speculate that the mRNA responsible for this is the same one that a deficit of which results in the pituitary overproducing TSH. While the current assumption in this field is that it must be the presence of an mRNA that causes this TSH production (or perhaps the absence of T4) I would suggest that it is, in fact, the absence of an mRNA that is to blame. Furthermore, the very same mRNA a deficit of which spurs TSH production results in these epigenetic changes to mitochronia, resulting in a more efficient mode of oxygen reclamation from glucose molecules, reducing overall O2 use.

The confirmation of this hypothesis would go a long way toward explaining the many reported cases of hypothyroidism that present with elevated TSH but normal T4 and T3 levels. In these patients, weight loss is not reported despite T4 supplementation. Symptoms of more severe thyroid deficiency such as dangerous hypothermia seem to be resolved by T4 supplementation, suggesting that perhaps it is not T4 or T3 that restores (at least partially) normal metabolism, but rather, this benefit is an indirect result of the thyroid being able to dedicate itself to the production of an entirely different, heretofore unidentified mRNA. The hormone may not be a hormone in the classical sense but may instead be an mRNA signal that controls mitochondrial gene expression. This may account for the failure of the scientific community to identify this mechanism to date.

Confirmation of this hypothesis may lead to a therapy that enables weight loss in patients with hypothyroidism who have reported experiencing difficulty in losing weight.

Once mitochronial gene expression/function has been altered as a result of actual (or perceived) chronic hypoxia, there is no extant mechanism for throwing all of the epigenetic switches back to their original position.

You may be wondering why, if the thyroid is actually an oxygen use-regulating organ (a paradigm shift in and of itself,) why the mitochondria becoming more efficient at using oxygen from glucose would result in weight retention.

The answer has to do with classical pulmonary respiration and Oxygen-CO2 exchange. An individual who has a more efficient oxygen metabolism (perhaps resulting from historical thyroid dysfunction) would not need to breathe as deeply (or exhale as completely) as an individual without these epigenetic changes. Shallow breathing results in reduced expulsion of CO2 and thus, their chronically higher serum CO2 levels result in weight retention. In cases of persistent thyroid-associated weight gain, rigorous aerobic exercise i.e. it involves heavy breathing, resolves the weight retention issues reported by those individuals.

I can therefore conclude that by restoring the default mode of mitochrondrial oxygen metabolism (by forcing the mitochonrial epigenetic profile back to its original configuration,) the patient would be forced to inhale and exhale more deeply even when not exercising (something which cannot be consciously controlled) and would as a consequence experience weight loss. While their ability to hold their breath while under water would no longer be enhanced, they would likely be content with this tradeoff.

>>15045682
>Its hot in Iran too, why didn't they stay black?
skin pigmentation has little to do with how hot it is other than as a proxy for incident UV radiation, but the difference in such radiation between around the equator and the Middle East is huge
consider this: the capital of Iran, i.e. Tehran, is literally closer in latitude to most of Norway than it is to the equator, and to the Arctic Circle
UV radiation also drops off rather rapidly with latitude, especially averaged over a year due to how a low incident Solar angle means much less UV reaches the surface, whereas on the equator there's sunlight beating down every single day of the year, with the Solar angle varying between ~67 degrees to 90 degrees (directly overhead)
in comparison, right now in e.g. Oslo, Norway, the Solar angle at the highest point of the day is only 7 degrees, Sol barely peeks over the horizon before setting again, and there is zero UV reaching the surface at all
for comparison, in Tehran the Solar angle in the winter is around ~32 degrees, which also means negligible UV
a good rule of thumb is that your shadow should be as tall or taller than you for UV to be reaching you, i.e. a Solar angle of 45 degrees or more, and that only happens in Tehran from around the beginning of March to the end of October
